Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Civic Science: Reframing the Role of Science in Society, October 2-3, 2014 in Washington, DC

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This workshop will bring together scientists, philosophers, administrators, community organizers, policy makers, and legislators to examine civic science. The main goals are to delineate what civic science is, to specify how it differs from citizen science and activist street science, and to generate best practices for civic science. The proposers also hope to develop strategies to impact policy discussions and professional education, and to make some headway towards shifting the national conversation about the role of science in society.


This work should help foster the collective capacities of scientists and non-scientists to come together to solve real-world problems in a democratic society. A white paper will be produced

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant funded a workshop that was held at the National Science Foundation on October 2-3, 2014 in Washington DC. The workshop was attended by 55 scholars and citizens across the two days. Attendees were from diverse circles that included scientists from research universities, scientists from community colleges, scientists from the private sector, scholars from the fields of history and civic studies, scholars with expertise in community organizing, representatives from private foundations, citizens with an interest in science and science education, and representatives from federal agencies including NSF, NIH Office of Behavioral and Social Sciences Research, US Department of Agriculture, and USAID.

The workshop clarified the need to make science a more integral part of discussions within communities and community action. All attendees shared the view that science must play an integral role in a healthy democracy. The question is: what role should science -- and scientists -- play?

At present, scientific information is often used within an 'expert' framing, where scientists are called upon to share their knowledge, and then democratic deliberation commences. This creates barriers between scientists and citizens, often devaluing citizen input. More critically, these barriers prevent citizens from playing a role in knowledge creation. Civic science holds the promise of an alternative view, where scientists and citizens co-create knowledge.

This type of approach is currently being used by a number of other groups. Most notably, 'citizen science' and 'community based participatory research' all share concepts being used by proponents of 'civic science'. Thus, we spent a considerable amount of time trying to understand how these approaches relate. The group concluded that civic science embraces the concept of democracy and democratic engagement more centrally than the other approaches. Indeed, civic science might be viewed as a general umbrella concept that could integrate the other more specialized concepts that are currently being used by specific groups.

The workshop concluded with several action items to spur further discussion. These activities are summarized below.

  • We formed an exploratory committee charged with further developing the civic science concept. This committee met for an initial organizing conference call in January 2016.
  • On February 5, the University of Minnesota’s Institute for Child Development hosted a dialogue between proponents of civic science and scientists studying executive function, both of which are being used to address the achievement gap – http://www.cehd.umn.edu/icd/events/ICDsymposium/
  • On February 19, Harry Boyte published a blog in the Huffington Post on an “emerging conversation”  between civic science/civic agency and executive function - https://www.academia.edu/10943684/Civic_Agency_and_Executive_Function_--_An_Emerging_Conversation
  • On March 11, Harry Boyte delivered an address to the Gates Foundation’s SxSW.edu Pathways to Student Success concluding session. This address included an extended analysis of the overlapping themes that link research on executive function and notions of civic science/civic agency
  • Educational Theory, the field’s leading journal, invited an essay from Boyte for its issue on the Centennial of John Dewey’s Democracy and Education. The piece, co-authored with Margaret Finders, chair of the Department of Education at Augsburg College, includes a section on the interdisciplinary field of civic studies/civic agency.
